{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3521364,"name":"","username":"robojack","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/49beb7/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-09T15:09:29.235Z","cooked":"

I want to have a second micro SD card as a backup. NI says lower capacity ones are better but finding 4GB seems iffy if you read the reviews. Has anyone purchased a 4/8 GB card that has worked well for them. I just don’t want to play games with getting them and checking them out and returning them.

I’ve read the posts in

RoboRio 2 Micro SD Card ejection Control System
Over the weekend our team competed in the FIM St Joe event. During the event we were making use of the RoboRio 2.0 micro SD card slot to keep a copy of known good code ready to go. During one of the swap outs we noted that the micro SD card would no longer stay in the RoboRio. Has any other team experienced this? We did have a few mentors from other teams look at this as well and nobody could explain it. We will be in contact with National Instruments about this.

about them getting knocked out of the roboRIO and the last thing we want to do is scramble around during a match looking for one.

I have tried 32GBs and maybe 1 16GB and they have universally failed to work in the roboRIO . I can mount them on a Linux system and they read just fine but won’t read on the RIO. I was trying to demo last year’s unit to some new students and when I put it in teleop and enabled it, it went bananas and spun in circles hitting things in the lab. Fortunately nobody was close but I don’t ever want to see that again. It did throw off a camera I was testing and completely destroyed it. All testing of new cards will be done with the unit on blocks until we’re sure. Other cards I tried had just not worked but this one just went crazy.

Long story short does anyone have recommendations for a safe micro SD card for the roboRIO?

Thanks for any thoughts

It is pricier but is is better to use an SLC SD card.
I have used these with no problems https://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/SanDisk/SDSDQED-008G-XI?qs=gZXFycFWdAPa9LVRVbu4nw%3D%3D&countryCode=US&currencyCode=USD

Do your SD cards have a little symbol on them that looks like this?

If so, try one that doesn’t have the little U with a number in it. Ideally, find one that says SDHC or SDMMC on it.

Newer, high-end microSD card frequently abandon support for the legacy SPI and/or MMC protocols, supporting only SD.

I’m not sure what protocols the Rio supports. If I had to guess, it’s probably MMC. A lot of embedded stuff in the 2010s used MMC-based storage. Your best bet is name-brand, low-speed cards. Odd combo, I know, but those cards tend to retain compatibility with MMC while the higher-speed/higher-capacity cards don’t.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-02-09T15:38:57.328Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":183,"readers_count":182,"score":36.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":490880,"topic_slug":"micro-sd-cards-for-the-roborio-2","display_username":"evanperryg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20861,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1732 ← 3007 ← 2338"},"post_url":"/t/micro-sd-cards-for-the-roborio-2/490880/3","custom_user_title":"1732 ← 3007 ← 2338","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3537099,"name":"","username":"robojack","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/49beb7/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-23T13:34:36.517Z","cooked":"

After trying a number of microSD cards and having no luck, I let it go for a while. Over the weekend, I thought I’d look at it again. Going to the FIRST installation section for roboRIO-2 installation, I found it seems to have changed to show a video about how to do it. What the heck I watched it. At the end, it had a section about using the Imaging tool to set the team number on the roboRIO after installing the new card. I did that and amazingly it fixed the problem. There were now also words somewhere in this that said ANY sized microSD card would work. I know before there were words about smaller ones working better.

Was this an obvious known solution before and I missed it or is this something new that was corrected recently?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-02-23T13:34:36.517Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":101,"readers_count":100,"score":25.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":490880,"topic_slug":"micro-sd-cards-for-the-roborio-2","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60576,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/micro-sd-cards-for-the-roborio-2/490880/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3537107,"name":"Joe Ross","username":"Joe_Ross","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_ross/{size}/37_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-23T14:10:25.917Z","cooked":"

The video has been there since last March, and the text section that says to set the team number has been there since the article was written 4 years ago. There’s even a pinned thread on chiefdelphi: PSA: Set the team number on your roborio 2 after reimaging

robojack:

I can mount them on a Linux system and they read just fine but won’t read on the RIO.

When I read this, I made the assumption that the status light was reporting an unrecoverable error, which was obviously a wrong assumption. If you had said that the deploy process couldn’t find the roboRIO after imaging the SD card, or the driver station wouldn’t connect after imaging the SD card, I think people would have pointed you in the right direction. This is a good example of the XY Problem

robojack:

There were now also words somewhere in this that said ANY sized microSD card would work. I know before there were words about smaller ones working better.

That text has also been there since the article was written, 4 years ago.

Wow. I really missed that Not sure how but I did.

Another example of where “It’s better to remain silent and be thought a fool than open your mouth and remove all doubt.”

Apologies for wasting the bandwidth.

Being silent isn’t the lesson that I’d learn from this, but rather that taking time to validate your memory and your assumptions is a part of the engineering process.

It’s actually a lesson taught through repetition: verify your known’s/assumptions. Often you have made a mistake and simply overlooked it as too simple to be the problem.
